titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Edward Pendleton Herring papers FA1287

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-09-12 00:04:29 -0400.

physdesc.extent: 8 letter document boxes, 12 legal document boxes, and 1 half-letter document box

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Born in Baltimore, Maryland on October 27, 1903, E. Pendleton Herring was a political scientist, writer, and foundation executive. He earned an AB in English in 1925 and a PhD in political science in 1928, both from Johns Hopkins University. Herring's dissertation, Group Representation Before Congress, was published in 1929. Upon graduating, Herring served as a faculty member in Harvard University's Department of Government from 1928 to 1947 and as Secretary of Harvard's Graduate School of Public Administration from 1936 to 1947. In this period, he published five books: Public Administration and the Public Interest, Federal Commissioners: A Study of Their Careers and Qualifications, Presidential Leadership: The Political Relations of Congress and the Chief Executive, The Politics of Democracy: American Political Parties in Action, The Impact of War: Our American Democracy under Arms.

From 1940-1944, Herring worked as a part-time consultant to the US Budget Bureau for the Records of War Administration. During World War II, Herring served on advisory committees for the army, navy, and air force. In 1941, Herring took an active role in the organization of the Historical Division of the War Department. From July-September 1945, he worked as a consultant to the Secretary of the Navy's associate, Ferdinand Eberstadt. His work in this position produced the Eberstadt report which led to the National Security Act of 1947, thus creating the Department of Defense, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the National Security Council, and the Central Intelligence Agency. He was awarded the Navy Citation and Distinguished Civilian Service Award in 1946 for his work with Eberstadt. In 1946, he became director of the United Nations Atomic Energy Group and left Harvard to work for the Carnegie Corporation from 1946 to 1948.

Herring became President of the Social Science Research Council (SSRC) in 1948 and served in that capacity until 1968. Under his governance, the SSRC's annual budget grew from $500,000 when he took the office to more than $2 million when he left. Herring also served as President of the American Political Science Association from 1952-1953. Herring became President of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation in 1962 and served in that role for nearly thirty years. Herring was also an active member of the American Historical Society, the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia, the Council on Foreign Relations, the American Society for Public Administration, the Cosmos Club, the Century Association in New York, and the Harvard Club in New York.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Edward Pendleton Herring papers are arranged into two series: 1. Institutional Files 2. General Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Edward Pendleton Herring papers primarily consist of materials related to Herring's long-time role as president of the Social Science Research Council (SSRC), but also contain reports, correspondence, and clippings connected to his military advisory positions during World War II and his leadership in societies and clubs, including the American Political Science Association, the International Political Science Association, the Comitato per le Scienze Politiche e Sociali (COSPOS), the International Social Science Council, and the Cosmos Club. The institutional files and correspondence reflect Herring's capacity as a foundation executive and academic political science researcher as well as his participation in international projects like Growth of Democracy Abroad (GODA) and the Foreign Area Fellowship Program (FAFP).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This material was transferred to RAC in 2000 by Edward Pendleton Herring and ingested by RAC as Accession 2000:066.
